questions.text: A 59-year-old woman is brought to the emergency room after collapsing at home. She had been sitting on her couch reading, when she started feeling lightheaded and lost consciousness. According to her husband, she was unconscious for approximately 30 seconds. Since regaining consciousness, she has continued to be lightheaded and dizzy. She has not had palpitations. Her only medication is simvastatin for hyperlipidemia. Her pulse is 37/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 92/55 mm Hg. An ECG is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Dopamine can be used to treat patients with unstable bradycardia. However, it is usually administered to patients who are unresponsive to first-line treatment.

B) INCORRECT:

Aggressive fluid repletion is typically used to treat patients with hypovolemic shock. This patient's hypotension is likely caused by bradycardia rather than hypovolemia. Although fluids can be administered to patients with unstable bradycardia for immediate hemodynamic support, more restrictive fluid repletion strategies (e.g., fluid challenge) are indicated.

C) CORRECT:

Atropine is an anticholinergic agent that is used to increase heart rate. Intravenous atropine is the first-line treatment in patients who present with unstable bradycardia. Asymptomatic patients do not require treatment.
Image Description:

ACS: acute coronary syndrome
CCBs: calcium channel blockers
ECG: electrocardiogram
IV: intravenous
PPM: permanent pacemaker
TTE: transthoracic echocardiography

D) INCORRECT:

Epinephrine can be used to treat bradycardia and hypotension and may also be considered for hemodynamically unstable patients with symptomatic bradycardia. However, epinephrine is usually administered to patients who are unresponsive to first-line treatment.

E) INCORRECT:

Glucagon can be administered to patients with symptomatic bradycardia that is not responsive to therapy with the first-line agent. Glucagon is also indicated in patients with suspected drug-induced bradycardia (e.g., due to beta blockers) or severe hypoglycemia.

F) INCORRECT:

Transcutaneous pacing (TCP) is indicated in patients with unstable bradycardia for which pharmacotherapy alone either is ineffective, not readily available, or contraindicated.
questions.hint: This patient presents with symptomatic, unstable sinus bradycardia.

questions.text: An 80-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of fatigue and lightheadedness. He does not have chest pain, palpitations, or difficulty breathing. He has a history of hyperlipidemia, hypertension, and osteoarthritis. Seven months ago, he had a myocardial infarction. His medications are simvastatin, lisinopril, metoprolol, and ibuprofen. His pulse is 48/min and blood pressure is 89/50 mm Hg. He responds slowly to questions but is oriented to person, place, and time. Examination shows dry mucous membranes. His lungs are clear to auscultation and bowel sounds are positive, with no pulsatile masses or bruits. Pedal pulses are nonpalpable, distal extremities are cold, and capillary refill time is 4 seconds. An ECG shows left axis deviation, a pathologic Q wave in lead III, a wide QRS complex, and a constant PR interval of 0.15 seconds; every third P wave is nonconducted. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Amiodarone is typically indicated for the management of refractory ventricular and supraventricular tachyarrhythmias. This drug is associated with an increased risk of sinus bradycardia and AV nodal block and is therefore contraindicated in this patient who is already bradycardic and has a second-degree AV block.

B) INCORRECT:

Glucagon is used in the treatment of patients with beta-blocker poisoning, which can manifest with bradycardia and signs of cardiogenic shock. However, ECG in patients with beta-blocker poisoning typically shows sinus bradycardia and a prolonged PR interval, consistent with first-degree AV block. This patient presents with a Mobitz type II AV block, for which glucagon is not indicated.

C) INCORRECT:

Digoxin decreases AV node conduction and is used to treat atrial fibrillation and heart failure in treatment-resistant cases. This drug is contraindicated in patients with second-degree AV block because it can worsen AV conduction delay and thereby increase the risk of complete AV block.

D) INCORRECT:

Adenosine decreases AV node conduction and is typically indicated for the acute management of persistent paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia. This drug is contraindicated in patients with second-degree AV block because it can worsen AV conduction delay and thereby increase the risk of complete AV block.

E) CORRECT:

Mobitz type II AV block is an unstable bradyarrhythmia that requires immediate treatment because it can progress to third-degree heart block and death. The first step in management is to determine hemodynamic status. Unstable patients require immediate treatment with transcutaneous (or transvenous) cardiac pacing. Placing a transcutaneous pacemaker is only a temporary measure until the patient is hemodynamically stable and can be further evaluated and treated for reversible causes of AV block. In patients with no reversible causes, definitive treatment includes placement of a permanent pacemaker to bypass the AV nodal block.

In addition to temporary cardiac pacing, prompt treatment with atropine and beta-adrenergic agents (e.g., dopamine, dobutamine, epinephrine) may be indicated. Administration of IV atropine is the first-line treatment for most cases of symptomatic bradycardia. However, in patients with an infranodal block, such as Mobitz type II AV block, atropine is often ineffective and may in rare cases worsen the symptoms.
Image Description:

15-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

– Irregularly irregular rhythm
– Atrial rate ~70/min, ventricular rate ~40/min
– Left axis deviation (LAD): R > S in lead I (+), R < S in II and aVF (-)
– Right bundle branch block (RBBB): QRS is widened (∼150 ms) with RBBB morphology (green overlay).
– Left anterior fascicular block (LAD and qR in aVL)
– Regular P waves throughout (red overlay), with intermittent nonconducted P waves (circled P)
– AV conduction ratio (P:QRS): initially 3:2, then 2:1
– PR interval: prolonged (∼240 ms) but constant in the conducted beats

The intermittent nonconducted P waves, with constant PR in the conducted beats, indicate Mobitz II second-degree atrioventricular block (which may have a regular conduction ratio or be completely irregular). The combination of RBBB and left anterior fascicular block represents a bifascicular block.
questions.hint: This patient is hemodynamically unstable (lightheadedness, hypotension, cool extremities, delayed capillary refill) with ECG evidence of a Mobitz type II AV block (bradycardia with a constant PR interval and regular nonconducted P waves in a 3:2 ratio), which is typically due to an infranodal block.

questions.text: A 64-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department after a syncopal episode 2 hours ago while grocery shopping. She has been feeling fatigued and lightheaded for the past couple of days. She has hypertension. Current medications include carvedilol. She appears diaphoretic. She is oriented to person but not to place or time. Her blood pressure is 95/62 mm Hg. An ECG is shown. A bolus of intravenous atropine is administered, after which vital signs remain unchanged. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Observation with continuous telemetry may be an appropriate option for patients with asymptomatic and hemodynamically stable bradycardia. Hemodynamically unstable patients with third-degree AV block, however, require intervention, as they are at high risk of asystole and sudden cardiac death.

B) INCORRECT:

Adenosine causes a short-term heart block by slowing down conduction in the atrioventricular node. It is used for the diagnosis and termination of certain forms of paroxysmal tachyarrhythmias (e.g., AVNRT and orthodromic AVRT) but would worsen this patient's heart block.

C) CORRECT:

Transcutaneous (or transvenous) cardiac pacing is indicated in patients with symptomatic high-risk AV blocks (e.g., Mobitz type II block or third-degree block). Transcutaneous pacing is only a temporary measure. Once the patient is stabilized, the cause of the third-degree AV block should be investigated, followed by a long-term solution (e.g., permanent cardiac pacing) if no reversible cause is found. This patient's third-degree AV block is likely an adverse effect of her medication (a beta blocker) and may be reversed with drug discontinuation.
Image Description:

ACS: acute coronary syndrome
CCBs: calcium channel blockers
ECG: electrocardiogram
IV: intravenous
PPM: permanent pacemaker
TTE: transthoracic echocardiography

D) INCORRECT:

The implantation of a cardiac defibrillator is indicated in patients at high risk for ventricular tachycardia and ventricular fibrillation to prevent sudden cardiac death due to arrhythmia. However, there is no evidence of ventricular arrhythmia in this patient and a permanent defibrillator would not address her third-degree AV block.

E) INCORRECT:

Amiodarone is a class III antiarrhythmic medication that can be used in patients with ventricular arrhythmia, supraventricular arrhythmia, and cardiac arrest. Since amiodarone decreases AV node conduction and would thus exacerbate this patient's third-degree AV block, it is contraindicated here.
questions.hint: This patient's ECG shows a slow ventricular rhythm (∼ 27/min) with complete dissociation between P waves and QRS complexes. These findings are consistent with a third-degree atrioventricular block (complete AV block). Her hypotension and confusion should raise concern for inadequate perfusion and impending shock.

Her pulse rate is 37/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 92/55 mm Hg. Electrocardiography is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

A) INCORRECT:

B) CORRECT:

questions.text:
An 82-year-old man presents with acute chest pain radiating to his jaw. He appears pale and diaphoretic and complains of dizziness. Physical examination reveals weak peripheral pulses and clear lung fields (see lab result and report).


Heart rate
42/min


Blood pressure
80/50 mm Hg




Test
Result
Normal Values


Troponin I
1.2 mg/L
0 - 0.4 mg/L


ECG: ST-segment elevations in leads II, III, and aVF
Which of the following is the most appropriate initial intervention to address his bradycardia?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Metoprolol, a beta blocker, reduces myocardial oxygen demand but is contraindicated in symptomatic bradycardia and hypotension. It exerts negative chronotropic and inotropic effects, further slowing heart rate and lowering blood pressure. In inferior myocardial infarction with AV nodal ischemia, metoprolol exacerbates conduction delay and impairs cardiac output.

B) INCORRECT:

Intravenous dopamine increases heart rate and contractility through beta-adrenergic stimulation, but its dose-dependent effects include alpha-adrenergic vasoconstriction, raising myocardial oxygen demand. In inferior myocardial infarction, bradycardia often results from AV nodal conduction delay due to vagal tone. Dopamine's broader catecholaminergic actions are less targeted for correcting this specific conduction abnormality.

C) INCORRECT:

Transcutaneous pacing provides temporary electrical stimulation to the myocardium in bradycardia cases, especially with high-degree AV block or when pharmacologic interventions fail. However, it is typically reserved for refractory bradycardia. In cases of bradycardia due to increased vagal tone, as seen in inferior myocardial infarction, pharmacologic agents like atropine are preferred initially due to their rapid onset and ease of administration.

D) CORRECT:

In acute inferior myocardial infarction, bradycardia often results from increased vagal tone affecting the atrioventricular (AV) node, leading to decreased heart rate and reduced cardiac output. Intravenous atropine, a muscarinic acetylcholine receptor antagonist, blocks parasympathetic stimulation, increasing heart rate and improving hemodynamic stability. Its rapid action makes it the first-line treatment for symptomatic bradycardia, especially when hypotension is present, by reducing vagal influence on the heart and restoring adequate heart rate.

Key learning point: In the setting of symptomatic bradycardia following an acute myocardial infarction, intravenous atropine is the first-line treatment to increase heart rate and improve hemodynamics.

questions.text: You are seeing a 59-year-old woman who is brought to the emergency department after collapsing at home. She was unconscious for about 30 seconds. Since regaining consciousness, she remains lightheaded and dizzy. She denies palpitations. Her only medication is simvastatin for hyperlipidemia. Her pulse is 37/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 92/55 mm Hg. Electrocardiography is provided. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Glucagon can be administered to patients with symptomatic bradycardia that is not responsive to therapy with the first-line agent. Glucagon is also indicated in patients with suspected drug-induced bradycardia (e.g., due to beta blockers) or severe hypoglycemia.

B) INCORRECT:

Dopamine can be used to treat patients with unstable bradycardia. However, it is usually administered to patients who are unresponsive to first-line treatment.

C) INCORRECT:

Epinephrine can be used to treat bradycardia and hypotension and may also be considered for hemodynamically unstable patients with symptomatic bradycardia. However, epinephrine is usually administered to patients who are unresponsive to first-line treatment.

D) INCORRECT:

Transcutaneous pacing (TCP) is indicated in patients with unstable bradycardia for which pharmacotherapy alone either is ineffective, not readily available, or contraindicated.

E) CORRECT:

Atropine is an anticholinergic agent that is used to increase heart rate. Intravenous atropine is the first-line treatment in patients who present with unstable bradycardia. Asymptomatic patients do not require treatment.

Key learning point: Intravenous atropine is the first-line treatment for unstable bradycardia to rapidly increase heart rate and improve perfusion.
Image Description:

ACS: acute coronary syndrome
CCBs: calcium channel blockers
ECG: electrocardiogram
IV: intravenous
PPM: permanent pacemaker
TTE: transthoracic echocardiography
questions.hint: This patient presents with symptomatic, unstable sinus bradycardia.

questions.text: You are seeing a 64-year-old woman who is brought to the emergency department after experiencing a syncopal episode 2 hours ago. She reports feeling fatigued and lightheaded over the past few days. Her medical history includes hypertension, and her current medication is carvedilol. On examination, she is diaphoretic and oriented to person but not to place or time. Her blood pressure is 88/62 mm Hg. Electrocardiography is provided. After administration of a bolus of intravenous atropine, her vital signs remain unchanged. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The implantation of a cardiac defibrillator is indicated in patients at high risk for ventricular tachycardia and ventricular fibrillation to prevent sudden cardiac death due to arrhythmia. However, there is no evidence of ventricular arrhythmia in this patient and a permanent defibrillator would not address her third-degree AV block.

B) INCORRECT:

Observation with continuous telemetry may be an appropriate option for patients with asymptomatic and hemodynamically stable bradycardia. Hemodynamically unstable patients with third-degree AV block, however, require intervention, as they are at high risk of asystole and sudden cardiac death.

C) INCORRECT:

Adenosine causes a short-term heart block by slowing down conduction in the atrioventricular node. It is used for the diagnosis and termination of certain forms of paroxysmal tachyarrhythmias (e.g., AVNRT and orthodromic AVRT) but would worsen this patient's heart block.

D) CORRECT:

Transcutaneous (or transvenous) cardiac pacing is indicated in patients with symptomatic high-risk AV blocks (e.g., Mobitz type II block or third-degree block). Transcutaneous pacing is only a temporary measure. Once the patient is stabilized, the cause of the third-degree AV block should be investigated, followed by a long-term solution (e.g., permanent cardiac pacing) if no reversible cause is found. This patient's third-degree AV block is likely an adverse effect of her medication (a beta blocker) and may be reversed with drug discontinuation.

Key learning point: Hemodynamically unstable third-degree AV block requires immediate transcutaneous cardiac pacing as a temporary measure until definitive therapy is established.
Image Description:

ACS: acute coronary syndrome
CCBs: calcium channel blockers
ECG: electrocardiogram
IV: intravenous
PPM: permanent pacemaker
TTE: transthoracic echocardiography

E) INCORRECT:

Amiodarone is a class III antiarrhythmic medication that can be used in patients with ventricular arrhythmia, supraventricular arrhythmia, and cardiac arrest. Since amiodarone decreases AV node conduction and would thus exacerbate this patient's third-degree AV block, it is contraindicated here.
questions.hint: This patient's ECG shows a slow ventricular rhythm (∼ 27/min) with complete dissociation between P waves and QRS complexes. These findings are consistent with a third-degree atrioventricular block (complete AV block). Her hypotension and confusion should raise concern for inadequate perfusion and impending shock.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman presents to the ED with fatigue for the past few hours. Her vital signs are BP, 95/60; P, 42; R, 16; oxygen saturation, 98% on room air. Her ECG is shown. What is the most appropriate initial intervention?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Defibrillation is indicated for pulseless patients with ventricular fibrillation or ventricular tachycardia. This patient has unstable bradycardia.

B) INCORRECT:

Transcutaneous pacing is a temporizing measure for unstable bradycardia that is refractory to first-line pharmacological intervention.

C) INCORRECT:

Dopamine infusion is a temporizing measure for unstable bradycardia that is refractory to first-line pharmacological intervention.

D) INCORRECT:

Epinephrine infusion is a temporizing measure for unstable bradycardia that is refractory to first-line pharmacological intervention.

E) CORRECT:

Correct -- Atropine is the first-line treatment for unstable bradycardia in adults. This patient presents with symptomatic bradycardia evidenced by hypotension, meeting criteria for unstable bradycardia requiring immediate intervention.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents to the ED with lightheadedness for the past few hours. Vital signs are BP, 85/50; P, 42; R, 16; oxygen saturation, 96% on room air. ECG shows complete heart block. His heart rate fails to improve with pharmacotherapy and transcutaneous pacing. The decision is made to proceed with transvenous pacing. What are the preferred vascular access sites for transvenous pacing?

choices.text: Right internal jugular vein and right subclavian vein
Right internal jugular vein and left internal jugular vein
Left internal jugular vein and left subclavian vein
Right internal jugular vein and left subclavian vein
Left internal jugular vein and right subclavian vein

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While the right internal jugular vein is a preferred vascular access site, the right subclavian vein does not provide the same straight anatomic pathway for transvenous lead placement.

B) INCORRECT:

While the right internal jugular vein is a preferred vascular access site, the left internal jugular vein does not provide the straightest anatomic pathway for transvenous lead placement.

C) INCORRECT:

Neither of these locations provides a straight anatomic pathway for transvenous lead placement.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- The right internal jugular vein and left subclavian vein provide the straightest anatomic pathway for transvenous lead placement.

E) INCORRECT:

While the right subclavian vein is a preferred vascular access site, the left internal jugular vein does not provide the straightest anatomic pathway for transvenous lead placement.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman presents to the ED with generalized fatigue for the past few hours. Vital signs are BP, 85/55; P, 40; oxygen saturation, 97% on room air. Her ECG shows sinus bradycardia. Her bradycardia is unresponsive to atropine, and the decision is made to initiate transcutaneous pacing. The pacer pads are applied to the patient, the pacing rate set to 70 beats per minute, and the current slowly increased. At 60 mA, pacer spikes followed by wide QRS complexes are observed on the monitor; however, her palpable pulse remains 40 beats per minute. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Decreasing the current output is inappropriate. This patient currently has electrical capture but lacks mechanical capture, indicating insufficient current to produce effective cardiac contraction.

B) CORRECT:

Correct – This patient demonstrates electrical capture (pacer spikes followed by wide QRS complexes) but lacks mechanical capture, as evidenced by the discrepancy between the set pacing rate of 70 beats per minute and the palpable pulse of 40 beats per minute. Increasing the current output is necessary to achieve mechanical capture, which represents effective cardiac contraction producing a palpable pulse that matches the pacing rate.

C) INCORRECT:

Repositioning the pacer pads is unnecessary since electrical capture has already been achieved, as demonstrated by the pacer spikes followed by wide QRS complexes on the monitor.

D) INCORRECT:

Increasing the pacing rate does not address the underlying problem of insufficient mechanical capture. The pacing rate is already appropriately set at 70 beats per minute, which is higher than the patient's native heart rate of 40 beats per minute.

E) INCORRECT:

Decreasing the pacing rate does not address the underlying problem of insufficient mechanical capture. The current pacing rate of 70 beats per minute is appropriately set above the patient's native heart rate.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman presents to the ED with lightheadedness. Vital signs are BP, 82/54; P, 42; R, 16; oxygen saturation, 97% on room air. ECG shows sinus bradycardia. Multiple IV attempts have been unsuccessful. What is the most appropriate immediate intervention?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Transvenous pacing is reserved for refractory bradycardia that does not respond to initial interventions. This procedure is time-consuming and invasive, making it inappropriate as an immediate intervention for unstable bradycardia when a faster, less invasive alternative is available.

B) INCORRECT:

Defibrillation is indicated for ventricular fibrillation and pulseless ventricular tachycardia, not for sinus bradycardia. This patient has an organized rhythm with hemodynamic instability that requires chronotropic support rather than rhythm termination.

C) CORRECT:

Correct – This patient presents with unstable bradycardia evidenced by hypotension. When IV access is unavailable, transcutaneous pacing is the first-line intervention for unstable bradycardia while attempting to establish vascular access.

D) INCORRECT:

Epinephrine can be used intravenously as a chronotropic agent for unstable bradycardia refractory to atropine, but the intramuscular route is not appropriate for this indication. Intramuscular epinephrine is primarily reserved for anaphylaxis and does not provide the immediate hemodynamic support needed for unstable bradycardia.

E) INCORRECT:

Magnesium sulfate is indicated for torsades de pointes, not for unstable bradycardia. This patient requires immediate chronotropic support to address hemodynamic instability from bradycardia.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man with hypertension presents with a 3-day history of progressive weakness and near syncope. He takes metoprolol 50 mg twice daily. Vital signs are BP, 125/85; P, 43; R, 18; oxygen saturation, 97% on room air. Physical examination shows clear lungs, normal heart sounds, and no acute distress. He has no symptoms at rest. His ECG is shown. What is the most appropriate management?

choices.text: Admit with continuous cardiac monitoring and cardiology consultation
Discontinue metoprolol and discharge with cardiology follow-up

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Atropine is indicated for unstable bradycardia with signs of shock, altered mental status, or acute heart failure. This patient has stable bradycardia without hemodynamic compromise, making atropine unnecessary.

B) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient has symptomatic second-degree atrioventricular block manifesting with weakness and near-syncope. Symptomatic stable bradycardia requires inpatient cardiology consultation and continuous cardiac monitoring to assess for progression to higher-grade blocks that can cause sudden cardiac death.

C) INCORRECT:

While metoprolol may contribute to bradycardia, symptomatic patients with second-degree atrioventricular block require inpatient monitoring to assess for progression to higher-grade blocks.

D) INCORRECT:

While high-dose glucagon therapy may be used to manage unstable patients with beta blocker poisoning, this patient shows no other symptoms of beta blocker poisoning (e.g., hypotension, CNS depression).

E) INCORRECT:

Transcutaneous pacing is reserved for unstable bradycardia or high-risk atrioventricular blocks. This patient has stable vital signs and is not in immediate distress, making emergency pacing inappropriate.
